Other Investors: Accel
Description*: SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE SAMPLE

Embracer acquired Cyprus-based mobile-puzzle studio Easybrain (Sudoku.com, Nonogram.com) for up to US $ 765 m(cash + new B shares). Easybrain became Embracer’s eighth operating group, giving the Swedish publisher a scaled ad-monetised mobile portfolio (>750 m installs, 12 m DAU) and strong data-driven UA expertise.

Carlyle acquired RuneScape publisher Jagex for an estimated $640,million, giving the PE firm control of a 20-year-old live-service MMO franchise with record 2020 subscribers and >$1 bn lifetime bookings, and providing capital for new IP and bolt-on M&A.

MTG is buying 100 % of Raid: Shadow Legends maker Plarium from Aristocrat Leisure for $620 m cash, with a performance-based earn-out of up to $200 m through 2028. The deal adds a top-grossing evergreen RPG franchise, >400 staff and a new R&D hub in Israel, roughly doubling MTG’s mobile-games revenue base.

Epic acquired Fall Guys parent Tonic Games Group—studios Mediatonic, Fortitude Games and The Irregular Corporation—to add a top-grossing, family-friendly multiplayer franchise, 300-plus dev talent and proprietary live-ops tech, supporting Epic’s cross-platform ambitions and broader metaverse strategy.

Sohu, already Changyou’s controlling shareholder, agreed to pay US $ 5.40 per Class A share / US $ 10.80 per ADS in cash (82 % premium) to buy out the remaining minority, valuing the TLBB / Legacy RuneScape publisher at about $579 m and taking it fully private on 17 Apr 2020.

U.S. asset-manager Macarthur Fortune bought RuneScape developer Jagex for $530 m in cash via its Platinum Fortune fund, acquiring the shares from Chinese owner Shanghai Hongtou Network. Jagex’s 400-person team and Cambridge HQ remained intact while the new owner pledged further investment in live-service growth.

Zynga bought UK mobile-games and animation-tech studio NaturalMotion for $527 m (cash + stock) to add hits CSR Racing and Clumsy Ninja, advanced physics/animation middleware, and a seasoned mobile team to accelerate its pivot from Facebook to smartphone free-to-play.

Zynga bought China-based Golf Rival studio StarLark from Betta Games for $525 m (cash + stock) to add a fast-growing PvP golf franchise, establish a first-party studio in China, and broaden its live-service sports portfolio

Vivendi launched a hostile cash offer at €8 per share, valuing mobile-games pioneer Gameloft at ~€700 m. Founder Michel Guillemot urged shareholders to resist, but a majority tendered by 26 June 2016, handing Vivendi control and setting the stage for its later (aborted) push on Ubisoft.

On 14 December 2020 iQIYI launched a registered offering of US $800 million aggregate principal amount of 4.00 % convertible senior notes due 2026. Pricing on 16 December set the notes at par with an initial conversion price of US $22.32 per ADS (44.8179 ADSs per US $1 000). Goldman Sachs (Asia) led the book alongside BofA Securities and J.P. Morgan; settlement occurred 21 December 2020. Net proceeds (~US $786 m) were earmarked for content investment and general corporate purposes; an additional US $100 m green-shoe was issued in January 2021.

Other Investors: Fidelity Investments, Franklin Templeton, Wellington Management
Description*:
On 2 Sep 2020 mobile-esports platform Skillz agreed to merge with NYSE-listed SPAC Flying Eagle

Acquisition Corp. The transaction contributed US $690 m of SPAC trust cash and a US $159 m PIPE led by Wellington, Fidelity, Franklin Templeton and Neuberger Berman, for total gross proceeds of ~US $849

m. The deal valued Skillz at an implied US $3.5 bn equity (US $3.6 bn EV) and closed on 16 Dec 2020; shares and warrants began trading as SKLZ / SKLZ WS on 17 December. Proceeds were earmarked to accelerate user-acquisition, product R&D and strategic M&A.

GameStop launched an at-the-market (“ATM”) equity program on 17 May 2024, authorising the sale of up to 45 million common shares. The company completed the program on 28 May 2024, issuing all shares and raising US $933.4 million in gross proceeds. Shares were sold at prevailing market prices through designated sales agents; no single investor was disclosed. GameStop will use the cash for general corporate purposes, including potential acquisitions, investments and balance-sheet reinforcement.

Indie-games publisher Devolver Digital joined London’s AIM on 4 November 2021 via a direct listing that placed no new shares. The admission valued the company at £ 694.6 million (≈ US $950 million). Existing shareholders (founders and management) retained a controlling stake; strategic partners NetEase and Sony Interactive Entertainment each acquired minority positions pre-listing. Liberum Capital acted as Nominated Adviser and sole broker for the float. The listing broadens Devolver’s shareholder base and provides a public currency to pursue further label acquisitions and talent partnerships.

Roblox launched and priced a US $1.0 billion senior-notes offering. The 3.875 % notes, due 15 October 2030, were issued at 100 % of par to qualified institutional buyers under Rule 144A and to non-US investors under Reg S. J.P. Morgan acted as lead left bookrunner with five additional joint book-runners. Net proceeds (~US $988 m after fees) were earmarked for general corporate purposes, including potential acquisitions, platform infrastructure investment, and working-capital needs.

On 9 June 2021 GameStop launched an at-the-market equity program for up to 5 million common shares, with Jefferies LLC acting as sole sales agent. The program was fully executed by 22 June 2021, raising US $1 126 million in gross proceeds at an average price of US $225.20 per share. GameStop stated that net proceeds would be used for “general corporate purposes,” including strengthening the balance sheet and investing in growth initiatives for its digital-commerce turnaround. No single investor was disclosed; shares were sold directly into the open market.

On 27 March 2025 GameStop priced a US $1.3 billion private offering of 0 % convertible senior notes due 2030 to qualified institutional buyers under Rule 144A. The company also granted the initial purchaser a 13-day option for an extra US $0.2 billion. Closing is scheduled for 1 April 2025. Net proceeds (~US $1.28 billion) will be used for general corporate purposes, including Bitcoin purchases under GameStop’s updated treasury policy. The notes are unsecured, carry no coupon, and are initially convertible at US $29.85 per share.

On 3 February 2021 Electronic Arts priced a two-tranche senior-notes deal totaling US $1.5 billion. The tranche relevant here is US $750 million of 1.850 % notes maturing 15 February 2031, issued at 99.855 % of par to yield 1.866 %. J.P. Morgan led a six-bank book-running syndicate. The notes, senior unsecured obligations of EA, settled on 17 February 2021. Net proceeds were earmarked for “general corporate purposes,” including part of the cash consideration required to close EA’s US $2.4 billion acquisition of Glu Mobile.

Other Investors: CPP Investments
Description*:
On 17 March 2021 Embracer executed the Nordics’ then-largest accelerated book-build, issuing 36 million new B-shares at SEK 210 to raise SEK 7.6 billion (~US $890 million). Long-only anchor CPP Investments invested alongside Capital Group, Alecta and other blue-chip institutions. The shares settled 18 March, diluting existing capital by ~4.3 %. Net proceeds were earmarked for Embracer’s acquisition pipeline and general corporate purposes.

 

* CPP Investments was highlighted in the release as the largest single subscriber (≈ SEK 1.9 bn allocation).

On 10 Apr 2023 Take-Two priced a US $1 b senior-notes offering split into US $500 m 5.000 % notes due 2026 and US $500 m 4.950 % notes due 2028, issued at par. Lead bookrunner J.P. Morgan, with Wells Fargo, BNP Paribas and BofA as joint book-runners, expects the notes to settle 14 Apr 2023. Net proceeds will repay Take-Two’s US $350 m term loan in full and fund general corporate purposes, including potential debt repurchases and share buy-backs.

On 8 June 2022 Embracer executed a SEK 10.3 billion (≈ US $1 billion) directed share issue to Savvy Gaming Group, the games-investment arm of Saudi Arabia’s PIF. Savvy bought 99.88 million new B-shares at SEK 103.47, giving it 8.1 % of share capital and 5.4 % of votes. Settlement occurred 15 June 2022; proceeds bolster Embracer’s M&A war-chest.

On 27 March 2025 Ubisoft announced the formation of a €4 bn subsidiary that will house its flagship franchises (Assassin’s Creed, Far Cry, Rainbow Six). Tencent will invest €1.16 bn (~US $1.25 bn) for a 25 % economic stake, with closing anticipated by year-end 2025. Cash proceeds will strengthen Ubisoft’s balance sheet and fund long-term growth of the new franchise-focused unit.

On 18 Aug 2023, AppLovin refinanced its capital structure by raising a US $1.5 b seven-year senior-secured Term-Loan B ("Amendment No. 9 Replacement Term Loans") at SOFR + 275 bp with a 0.50 % SOFR floor. JPMorgan led a seven-bank book-running syndicate that included KKR Capital Markets and BofA Securities. Proceeds were used to repay all existing term loans under AppLovin's credit agreement, extend maturity to August 2030 and lower the company's weighted-average cost of debt.

US-based gaming holding company Take-Two Interactive Software (NASDAQ: TTWO) announced a $600m senior notes offering. The offering will comprise two senior notes: $300m of 5.4% notes due 2029 and $300m of 5.6% notes due 2034. The funds will be used for general corporate purposes, such as repaying Senior Notes due 2025.

Other Investors: Abstract Ventures, Andreessen Horowitz, BoxGroup, RX3 Growth Partners, Spark Capital, vgames
Description*: US-based game developer Mountaintop Games has raised $30m in a Series B funding round. The funding came from YouTube and Twitch creators Shroud, tarik, iiTzTimmy, Cohh Carnage, songwriter Zedd, and NBA player Paul George. The company had already raised $35.5m in Seed and Series A rounds in 2021. Founded in 2020, Mountaintop is currently developing its first online game, a tactical FPS, the title of which is yet undisclosed.

Mobile-app monetisation platform AppLovin priced its Nasdaq IPO at US $80 a share, raising about US $2 billion and debuting on 15 April 2021 with a valuation near US $28.6 billion. Morgan Stanley served as lead global coordinator alongside a six-bank syndicate. Proceeds were earmarked for debt repayment, working capital and potential acquisitions to extend AppLovin’s advertising and gaming ecosystem.

Real-time 3D engine maker Unity priced its NYSE IPO at US $52 per share, the top of a twice-raised range, selling 25 million new shares to raise about US $1.3 billion. Trading opened on 18 September 2020, giving Unity an implied market capitalisation near US $8.7 billion. Goldman Sachs led a seven-bank syndicate. Proceeds were earmarked for R&D, debt repayment, and strategic acquisitions as Unity expanded beyond gaming into film, automotive and AR/VR industrial applications.

Israeli-founded mobile-games group Playtika completed its Nasdaq IPO on 15 January 2021, selling 69.5 million Class A shares at US $31 to raise US $1.86 billion. The pricing valued Playtika at roughly US $11.1 billion. Morgan Stanley led a consortium of eight bookrunners. Proceeds went to selling shareholder Alpha Frontier (a Giant Network–Yunfeng Capital vehicle); Playtika’s free-to-play casino and casual titles (Slotomania, House of Fun) remained headquartered in Herzliya, Israel.

On 5 Aug 2020 Activision Blizzard priced a $2 billion two-tranche senior-notes deal: $500 m 1.350 % notes due 2030and $1.5 bn 2.500 % notes due 2050. The issue settled 10 Aug 2020. BofA Securities led a syndicate of nine book-running managers. Net proceeds (~$1.98 bn) were earmarked to redeem outstanding 2021 and 2022 notes and for general corporate purposes, extending the company’s debt maturity profile at historically low coupons.

Embracer Group is spinning off its tabletop-games subsidiary Asmodee by distributing Asmodee class B shares to Embracer shareholders, followed by a direct listing on Nasdaq Stockholm on 7 February 2025. Asmodee’s shares will trade under ticker “ASMDEE”; class A shares remain unlisted.

Mobile monetisation platform ironSource agreed to merge with NYSE-listed SPAC Thoma Bravo Advantage on 21 Mar 2021. The deal supplied US $2.3 billion in gross cash led by Tiger Global, Counterpoint Global, Wellington and others) and valued ironSource at an equity value of US $11.1 billion. The combination closed on 29 Jun 2021; ironSource began trading as ticker “IS”, using proceeds for M&A and product R&D.

On 14 Dec 2020 Zynga launched a Rule 144A private placement of 0 % convertible senior notes due 2026. Pricing on 15 Dec set the base deal at US $762 million, with initial purchasers led by Morgan Stanley receiving a 13-day option for US $112.5 million more; the option was fully exercised, bringing the total to US $874.5 million. The notes settled 17 Dec 2020. Net proceeds (~US $857 million) funded capped-call transactions and general corporate purposes, including M&A. The notes mature 15 Dec 2026 and are redeemable after 20 Dec 2023 if stock-price conditions are met.

UK-based mobile casual game developer Tripledot Studios has officially confirmed the acquisition of the gaming division of US-based mobile gaming and ad tech company AppLovin (NASDAQ: APP) for $800m. The transaction includes $400m in cash and $400m in equity, giving AppLovin a 20% stake in Tripledot and is different from the originally discussed $900m. The transaction is expected to close in Q2’25. The deal covers 10 studios, including Machine Zone, PeopleFun, Magic Tavern, Lion Studios, Belka, Athena, Clipwire, Leyi, Zenlife, and Zero Gravity. As a result of the acquisition, Tripledot’s valuation has reached $2B.
Liftoff Announces Minority Growth Equity Investment from General Atlantic at $4.3 Billion Valuation

Other Investors: Dune Ventures
Description*: US-based mobile games developer Starform has secured $6m in a funding round led by BITKRAFT Ventures, with participation from Dune Ventures. The funds will support the company’s expansion and the continued development of Metalstorm, released in Nov’23 and has attracted 3 million players. Founded by ex-King veterans, the company’s total funding is $20.9m across 4 rounds.

Other Investors: Accel, Bessemer Venture Partners, Greenoaks Capital, Greylock Partners, Index Ventures, Tencent
Description*: Gaming platform Discord has raised $500 million in a new funding round led by Dragoneer Investment Group. Discord, which allows public and private groups to gather and chat by text, audio and video via its social platform, is now valued at $15 billion — more than double the $7.3 billion the company was worth in its previous round.
Sample Sample Sample Sample Sample Sample Sample Sample Sample Sample

Other Investors: Accel, Atomico, Benchmark Capital, Bessemer Venture Partners, D1 Capital Partners, Eurazeo, Headline, Institutional Venture Partners, LionTree
Description*: France-based NFT fantasy football gaming startup Sorare has raised $680m in a Series B round led by SoftBank. It is considered the largest Series B funding in Europe and the largest funding in the history of French Tech, which values the company at $4.3B.

Lead Investor / Acquirer: Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, Insight Partners, Smash Capital
Description*: Singapore-based monetization platform Coda Payments has raised $690m from Smash Capital, Insight Partners, and GIC. The investors have also acquired minority stake from the previous shareholders of the company. The proceeds will support cross-border payments and alternative app store initiatives.

Other Investors: Animoca Brands, Big Bets, Cosmos, Overwolf, Playstudios, Polygon Technology, Solana Ventures, Warner Music Group, zVentures
Description*: US-based Forte, which provides game developers with blockchain infrastructure, has closed a $725m Series B round, led by Sea Capital and Kora Management. This is the largest blockchain-gaming deal we observed this year — previously, this was a $680m round of Sorare, closed in Sep’21.

Other Investors: Appaloosa Management, Baillie Gifford, BlackRock, Fidelity Investments, Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, Park West Asset Management, T. Rowe Price
Description*: Epic Games has announced the completion of a $1B funding round, including a $200m strategic investment from Sony. The current equity valuation of the company is $28.7B, which represents a substantial (+65%) increase over Epic's previous funding round in August 2020 (raising $1.78B at $17.3B valuation).

Other Investors: Baillie Gifford, BlackRock, David Tepper, Fidelity Investments, Lightspeed Venture Partners, Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, The Venture Reality Fund, T. Rowe Price
Description*: American video game giant Epic Games has closed its $1.78B funding round at the $17.3B valuation, making it one of the most valuable private gaming companies in the world

From Software, developer of Elden Ring and Dark Souls, is the latest company to join the acquisition parade — sort of. Its parent company, the Kadokawa Corporation, decided to issue shares of its stock to Tencent Holdings and Sony Interactive Entertainment

Sony Corporation ("Sony") and Epic Games, Inc. ("Epic") are pleased to announce that Sony has agreed to make a strategic investment of $250 million to acquire a minority interest in Epic through a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sony. The investment cements an already close relationship between the two companies and reinforces the shared mission to advance the state of the art in technology, entertainment, and socially-connected online services.

US-based gaming company Epic Games has raised a $1.5B investment from The Walt Disney Company (NYSE: DIS). The investment marks Disney's significant entry into gaming, aiming for growth and expansion. The collaboration aims to create a new games and entertainment universe connecting Disney stories with Fortnite. In Mar’23, Epic Games announced Creators Economy 2.0, which significantly improved the payment system for developers and the process of creating custom experiences within Fortnite. In Dec’23, Epic Games launched Fortnite LEGO — the most extensive collaboration within Fortnite featuring the large gaming mode and a lot of cosmetics updates. Before launching Fortnite LEGO, Epic Games received a massive investment from KIRKBI, the owner of LEGO, so we expect similar collaborations with Disney.

US-based games developer, publisher, and creators of Unreal Engine Epic Games has closed a $2B round at $31.5B post-money equity valuation. The funding came from Sony Group Corporation and KIRKBI, a family-owned holding behind The Lego Group — each of the investors contributed $1B. The current equity valuation of Epic Games is ~10% higher than that of the last year when the company secured a $1B round ($200m of which came from Sony) at a $28.7B valuation.

Other Investors: Animoca Brands, Coinbase Ventures, Hashed, Pantera Capital
Description*: Thailand-based web3 platform Zentry has raised $140m, led by Binance Labs and with participation from Coinbase Ventures, Animoca Brands, Pantera Capital, Hashed, and other investors. Previously known as GuildFi, the company will use the investments to develop a universal Superlayer platform that will integrate games across all platforms into one. The rebranding also introduces a token conversion program, allowing GuildFi token holders to convert to the new Zentry token in a 1-for-10 split.

"UAE-headquartered Web3 games publisher Fenix Games has closed a $150m investment from Phoenix Group and Cypher Capital.

Fenix Games announced its establishment on the day of receiving the investment. The studio is co-founded by three former C-level executives of Mythical Games: Chris Ko (CEO), Matt Nutt (COO), and Rudy Koch (CBO). Founded in 2018, US-based Mythical Games is best known for its Blankos Block Party blockchain-powered game, which became the first everWeb3 game released on Epic Games Store"

Other Investors: Andreessen Horowitz, Battery Ventures, Canaan, Union Grove Venture Partners
Description*: US-based Forte, which provides game developers with blockchain infrastructure, has raised $185m in a Series A round led by Griffin Gaming Partners, reaching $1B valuation

US-based independent game company ProbablyMonsters, which builds and sustains a family of AAA game studios, has raised a $200m in Series A round led by LKCM Headwater Investments. The round is considered to be the largest Series A raise in game development to date.

Other Investors: Animoca Brands, FTX, LionTree, MoonPay, Sound Ventures, The Sandbox, Thrive Capital
Description*: Yuga Labs Closes $450 Million Seed Round of Funding, Valuing the Company at $4 Billion

Other Investors: Citigroup, Credit Suisse, J.P. Morgan, Mirae Asset Securities, NH Investment & Securities
Description*: South-Korean PUBG publisher Krafton priced its KOSPI IPO at ₩498 000 per share, raising $3.75 bn in South Korea’s second-largest float. Shares began trading on 10 Aug 2021, giving Krafton an opening-day market cap of ≈ $19.3 bn. Proceeds will fund global M&A and new PUBG-universe titles. Mirae Asset led a five-bank syndicate of international bookrunners.

Other Investors: Bank of America, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan, Morgan Stanley
Description*: AppLovin priced a four-tranche, $3.55 billion offering of senior unsecured notes due 2029, 2031, 2034 and 2054 at coupons ranging from 5.125 % to 5.950 %. Proceeds will repay existing term-loan facilities and for general corporate purposes. The deal settles 5 Dec 2024, with J.P. Morgan, BofA and Morgan Stanley leading the syndicate.

Other Investors: China International Capital Corp, Credit Suisse, J.P. Morgan
Description*: Nasdaq-listed games and internet firm NetEase completed a secondary IPO in Hong Kong, selling 171.5 million new shares at HK$123 each to raise about US$2.7 billion. Shares began trading on 11 June 2020, giving NetEase an opening market capitalisation near US$52.6 billion. Credit Suisse led the three-bank syndicate with CICC and J.P. Morgan.

Other Investors: Bank of America, BNP Paribas, J.P. Morgan, Wells Fargo
Description*: Take-Two priced a $2.7 b four-tranche senior-notes deal (3.300 % 2024s, 3.550 % 2025s, 3.700 % 2027s, 4.000 % 2032s). Proceeds, together with cash on hand, funded the cash portion of its Zynga acquisition; unused funds revert to general corporate purposes. The notes settled 14 Apr 2022, with J.P. Morgan leading a four-bank syndicate.

Other Investors: Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan, Morgan Stanley, UBS
Description*: Chinese video-games platform Bilibili completed a Hong Kong secondary IPO, selling 25 million new Class Z shares at HK $808 to raise about US $2.6 billion. Shares began trading on 29 March 2021, giving the company an opening market capitalisation near US $36.6 billion. Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan and UBS

PUBG publisher Krafton bought California-based Unknown Worlds (Subnautica) for $500 m cash up-front plus an earn-out of up to $250 m payable in 2026, giving it 100 % of the 120-person studio while allowing it to operate independently under founder Charlie Cleveland

Australian slots-to-mobile group Aristocrat bought Israeli mid-core studio Plarium for US$500 m cash, gaining hit titles like Raid: Shadow Legends and about 1,200 staff across Israel, Europe and the U.S.; deal announced 10 Aug 2017 and closed 20 Oct 2017.

Other Investors: Orient Hontai Capital
Description*: A consortium led by Ningxia Yilida Capital and Shanda’s CEO signed a definitive merger on 3 Apr 2015 to take Shanghai-based MMO publisher Shanda Games private for $7.10 per ADS (≈ $1.9 bn equity). The all-cash deal closed 18 Nov 2015, giving the buyer group 100 % control and ending Shanda’s 2009-15 NASDAQ listing.

Take-Two (2K label) acquired Borderlands creator Gearbox from Embracer for $460 m in newly issued Take-Two shares, giving it 100 % of the studio and its IP portfolio; signed 28 Mar 2024 and completed 11 Jun 2024.

South-Korean MMO studio Pearl Abyss bought Iceland’s CCP Games (EVE Online) for $225 m cash upfront and an earn-out of up to $200 m tied to CCP’s 2019-20 EBITDA. Deal announced 6 Sep 2018 and closed 12 Oct 2018; CCP’s 250-person team in Reykjavík, London and Shanghai now operates as an autonomous subsidiary while publishing/marketing rolls into Pearl Abyss.

Other Investors: Accel, Linkedsee Limited
Description*: Investor consortium led by IDG-Accel and chairman Leilei Wang signed a definitive merger agreement to take Beijing-based online-games publisher KongZhong private for $7.55 per ADS (40 ord. shares), valuing the company at ≈ $299 m; deal announced 1 Dec 2016, completed 13 Apr 2017, giving the consortium 100 % ownership and ending a 12-year NASDAQ listing

Saudi PIF-owned EGDC first bought 33.3 % of SNK for SR 813 m (~$217 m) on 26 Nov 2020, then launched a Korea-/Japan-dual tender offer at ₩37,197 per KDR, spending ₩522 bn (~$475 m) to lift its holding to 96.18 % by 15 Feb 2022—effectively taking control of the King of Fighters publisher before an expected KOSDAQ delisting.

srael-based mobile-games leader Playtika bought Finnish studio Reworks—maker of interior-design hit Redecor—paying $400 m cash for 80 % and an earn-out of up to $200 m for the rest, tied to 2022 EBITDA; if the target is missed, the residual transfers for $1. The deal adds a fast-growing lifestyle title (~$30 m 2021 rev.) and a Helsinki outpost to Playtika’s portfolio

MTG bought India-based PlaySimple for $360 m up-front (77 % cash, 23 % MTG shares) plus earn-out ≤ $150 m tied to 2021-25 performance, giving MTG full control of the word-game developer (9 live titles, ≈215 staff) and new exposure to India’s talent pool. Deal announced 2 Jul 2021; first-step close for 77 % on 30 Jul 2021.

KKR-backed mobile-ads platform AppLovin bought strategy-game powerhouse Machine Zone for about $330 m, adding Game of War, Mobile Strike and ~800 staff; deal announced 15 May 2020 and closed 19 May 2020, making it AppLovin’s largest acquisition to date.

Sweden’s Stillfront bought 100 % of Hamburg-based Goodgame Studios for €270 m (≈ $318 m) in cash and newly-issued shares, making Goodgame’s founders Stillfront’s largest shareholders (≈ 36 %). The deal adds the hit F2P franchises Empire and Big Farm, 300 staff and strong cashflow to Stillfront’s long-lifecycle portfolio; signed 7 Dec 2017, completed 15 Jan 2018.

Take-Two bought Belgrade-based mobile studio Nordeus for $225 m up-front ( $135 m cash + $90 m TTWO shares ) and a cash earn-out of up to $153 m tied to FY-22/23 EBITDA, gaining Top Eleven and ~180 staff to expand its sports and mobile footprint.

EA bought Titanfall creator Respawn for $315 m upfront (cash + RSUs) plus an earn-out of up to $140 m, giving it 100 % of the 200-person Los Angeles studio and its Star Wars & VR projects; deal signed 9 Nov 2017, closed 1 Dec 2017.

Israel-based mobile games developer Playtika (NASDAQ: PLTK) has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the Youda Games’ portfolio from Azerion (EURONEXT: AZRN), a European digital advertising and entertainment media platform. The portfolio includes social card-themed game Governor of Poker 3, apart from many others. The initial cash consideration for the acquisition is $89.4m (€81.3m), with a potential earnout that could raise the total consideration to up to $163.94m (€150m) subject to achieving curtain KPIs.

China’s Shandong Hongda Mining bought RuneScape developer Jagex for ≈ $300 m in cash, acquiring 100 % of shares from Insight Venture Partners, Raine Group & Spectrum Equity to diversify beyond mining and enter the global games market. The deal was announced 16 Mar 2016 and completed in July 2016.

Embracer bought Crystal Dynamics and two sister studios from Square Enix for $300 m, gaining ~1,100 staff plus IP such as Tomb Raider and Deus Ex. Deal signed 2 May 2022 and closed 26 Aug 2022, giving Embracer full ownership and control of the Western studios.

French hyper-casual giant Voodoo bought Israeli studio Beach Bum for an estimated $300 m, giving it full control of a 150-person team and hit tabletop titles (Backgammon Lord of the Board, Spades Royale) to deepen its in-app-purchase monetisation

Target Company: Good Job Games - Zen Match (IP sale)
Description*: Israeli mobile games giant Moon Active is acquiring Zen Match from Turkish developer Good Job Games, in addition to the associated Istanbul-based team.
Moon Active, the Israeli mobile-games unicorn behind Coin Master, purchased studio Melsoft Games (creator of Family Island and My Cafe), adding 240 staff and two top-grossing titles to its portfolio.
EG7 bought 100 % of US MMO studio Daybreak for USD 300 m to add titles EverQuest, DCUO and PlanetSide to its portfolio and double group revenue.
Stillfront acquired 100 % of California-based mobile studio Storm8 for up to $400 m ( $300 m cash/stock upfront plus a $100 m EBITDA-based earn-out)

Miniclip acquired 100 % of Copenhagen-based SYBO Games, developer of Subway Surfers (the most-downloaded mobile game of all time), to expand its casual-mobile footprint; existing SYBO leadership remains in place.
China's ByteDance said on Wednesday that its gaming unit Nuverse has acquired C4games, as it seeks to further expand into the video games business.

Sweden-based gaming holding Embracer Group (STO: EMBRAC B) has sold PC & console games developer Saber Interactive, for $247m to Beacon Interactive, a company owned by Saber’s original co-founder Matthew Karch.
Israeli social casino gaming giant Playtika has acquired Finnish mobile game publisher Seriously

Modern Times Group has announced the acquisition of London-based mobile studio Hutch for an expected $375 million. Of the total, $275 million is an up-front consideration, while the rest will stem from earn-out payments at an expected value of $100 total.
Zynga Acquires Leading Global Mobile Game Developer Gram Games; Team Behind Hit Titles Merge Dragons! and 1010!
New York based publisher Take-Two Interactive has acquired Barcelona-based mobile developer Social Point for $250 million with additional earn-outs of up to $25.9 million.

Sony Interactive Entertainment acquired Insomniac Games, the studio behind Marvel’s Spider-Man and Ratchet & Clank, for $229 million in August 2019. Insomniac became Sony’s 14th studio, strengthening PlayStation’s exclusive lineup while continuing under its current management

American mobile game developer and publisher Zynga Inc. (Nasdaq: ZNGA) has completed the acquisition of 80% of the shares in of Turkey-based hyper-casual game developer & publisher Rollic for $180m, which is $12m higher than the originally announced purchase price of $168m
Stockholm-based mobile game developer and publisher Stillfront Group has completed the acquisition of Jordan-based mobile game developer Jawaker.

Playtika acquired Wooga, a Berlin-based casual games company, on December 3, 2018. This acquisition marks Playtika's expansion into the casual games genre, with Wooga continuing to operate from Berlin under its current CEO, Jens Begemann. Playtika aims to leverage its expertise in live operations and AI to enhance Wooga's story-driven game development.

Sweden-based gaming giant Stillfront has completed the acquisition of Hong Kong-based mobile games publisher 6waves and has issued 2,913,857 new shares. 6waves adds several top-grossing strategy titles to Stillfront’s portfolio, and provides a platform with local expertise for further growth in East Asia.

Ubisoft has acquired 75% of Berlin-based developer, Kolibri Games. The studio, known for its experience in the mobile free-to-play space, is one of the leaders of the “idle” games genre and publishes Idle Miner Tycoon, which has been downloaded by more than 104 million players.
NYC-based video game publisher and developer Take-Two Interactive (NASDAQ:TTWO) has acquired NYC-based mobile puzzle games developer Playdots for $192m
Turkey-based hypercasual games publisher and developer Rollic, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Zynga, has acquired Germany-based hypercasual games developer Popcore for $165m.
US-based mobile games developer and publisher Jam City has completed the acquisition of Canada-based mobile game studio Ludia from Fremantle for $165m.

U.S. publisher Scopely has acquired competitive platformer Stumble Guys from Finnish developer Kitka Games for $160m. The battle royale party game – which may or may not remind you of another bumbling platformer called Fall Guys – has attracted more than 20 million daily players globally across iOS, Android, and Windows PC platforms.

1C Entertainment, the Polish studio behind games like King’s Bounty, announced today it has been acquired by Tencent. Tencent will hold the majority stake in the company, and it plans to rebrand the studios within six months.
Sweden-based mobile game developer and publisher Stillfront Group (OM:SF) has acquired 100% of San Francisco-based mobile game developer Super Free Games

Embracer Group finalized its acquisition of Saber Interactive for an initial $150 million, potentially rising to $525 million with earn-out payments. The upfront payment included $100 million in cash and $50 million in Embracer Group B shares.
Sea Limited (NYSE: SE), a leading global consumer internet company, announced that its digital entertainment arm, Garena, has completed the acquisition of 100% of Phoenix Labs,

EMK Capital LLP and Terry Malham acquired Outright Games Ltd. from Rockpool Investments LLP and others on August 5, 2021. The Founder Terry Malham, has reinvested alongside us and remains a substantial investor.

Stockholm-based investment holding company with assets in esports and gaming Modern Times Group has completed the acquisition of New Zealand-based mobile tower defense games developer Ninja Kiwi. The total consideration of the deals equals $189m and consists of $141.4m upfront and several earn-outs. You can read more about the deal here.

Embracer Group AB, through its wholly owned subsidiary Koch Media GmbH, has today entered into an agreement to acquire 100 percent of the shares in the Poland-based Flying Wild Hog from Supernova Capital
Stockholm-based mobile game developer and publisher Stillfront Group (OM:SF) has acquired 100% of Berlin-based PC & mobile MMORPG developer Sandbox Interactive

Sweden-based multiplatform games developer and publisher Enad Global 7 (ST: EG7) has entered into an agreement to acquire Russian PC MMORPG games publisher Innova for EUR 109.8m (~$132m). Innova will continue to operate as an independent publisher and a separate entity within the EG7 group
Korean publisher Netmarble Games has announced a $130 million cash injection to US mobile game publisher Jam City (SGN)
Stillfront Group completes the acquisition of 78% of the shares in Nanobit

Media and Games Invest (Verve), has acquired KingsIsle Entertainment Inc. for a fixed cash consideration of USD 126 million on a cash- and debt- free basis, plus up to USD 84 million that may be paid to the sellers as earn-out payment, dependent on the level of future revenues.
Tilting Point, a leading free-to-play games publisher, has acquired Budge Studios, one of the world’s biggest mobile developers within the children’s entertainment and education category.

Embracer has entered into an agreement to acquire US-based Perfect World Entertainment (PWE) for $125m paid 48% in cash and 52% in shares. Considering the purchase price of $103m and the financial performance of PWE (Net Sales’21 of ~$77m), the transaction multiple is 1.3x EV/Net Sales.
Canadian mobile game developer LEAF Mobile (TSXV:LEAF) has acquired Vancouver-based mobile game developer and publisher East Side Games for up to $125m.
Microsoft paid $117 million for Hellblade developer Ninja Theory to join Xbox

Tencent has made an offer to fully acquire Funcom, the games developer behind Conan Exiles (and others in the Conan franchise), Dune and some 28 other titles. The deal, when approved, would value the Oslo-based company at $148 million (NOK 1.33 billion) and give the company a much-needed cash injection to follow through on its longer-term strategy around its next generation of games.`

THQ Nordic AB (”THQ Nordic” or the “Company”) has today, through its wholly owned subsidiary, SALEM einhundertste Holding GmbH, entered into an agreement to acquire 100 percent of the share capital in Koch Media GmbH (“Koch Media”), which was announced earlier today through a press release, for a consideration of EUR 121 million on a cash and debt free basis (the “Transaction”).

Nordisk Film is upping its investment in Nordic game developers. Today, the company announced it will acquire all shares and full ownership of Just Cause and Mad Max developer Avalanche Studios--Nordisk's largest acquisition thus far.

China-based game giant NetEase (NASDAQ: NTES) has acquired France-based PC & Console games developer Quantic Dream for an undisclosed sum. NetEase, which became the minority shareholder of Quantic Dream in 2019, will now own 100% of the studio.
MTG invests EUR 82.6 million to increase shareholding in InnoGames from 21% to 51%
SciPlay Corporation (NasdaqGS:SCPL) agreed to acquire stake in Alictus A.S. for $300 million on March 1, 2022. As of March 1, 2022 SciPlay has acquired 80% stake in Alictus.
Internal information: [IS INCOMPLETE] [2025-09-02 12:02]: 071 Labs — Please complete company information and update their status.

Description*: China-based tech giant Tencent Holdings Ltd. (SEHK: 700) has acquired a majority stake of German PC&console game developer Yager. The amount of the transaction remains undisclosed.

Embracer Group, via its subsidiary Saber Interactive, is acquiring US-based Aspyr Media for $100 million ($60M cash, $40M shares), with up to $350M extra if targets are met. Aspyr, with 140 staff and $40.6M 2020 revenue, will operate as a standalone entity under Saber.
Founded in 2013, Ilyon Games is best known as a casual developer with titles such as Bubble Shooter, Cookie Rush, and Power Pop Bubbles. Tencent-owned Miniclip purchases Ilyon Games for $100 million.

Jam City has acquired TinyCo, a San Francisco-based studio specializing in adapting major Hollywood brands into successful mobile games, including Family Guy: The Quest for Stuff and Marvel Avengers Academy. This strategic acquisition, supported by a $130 million investment from Netmarble.

Canada-based PC & console UGC platform developer Voldex has acquired the Brookhaven  from UGC content developer Wolfpaq for an undisclosed sum. While the exact valuation remains undisclosed, the estimate is above the $100m mark.
Switzerland-based Mobile games developer and publisher Miniclip has acquired Head Ball 2 maker Masomo for $100m

UK-based multiplatform video game developer Sumo Group has completed the acquisition of Lake Street Labs Buyer Corp, the owner of Oregon-based console game developer Pipeworks Studio for a total consideration price of up to $99.5m

Korean media and entertainment giant Kakao Games recently announced it has acquired a 53% controlling stake in XLGAMES, developer of games such as ArcheAge and more recently, Moonlight Sculptor. Kakao Games will now have a strong game studio and new IPs added to its growing games portfolio.

Today, leading game development outsourcing company Keywords Studios (LON: KWS) has acquired UK-based outsource games developer The Multiplayer Group (MPG) from Improbable for $97m (£76.5m). The deal implies the multiples of around 5x-7x forward EV/EBITDA 24.
Stockholm-based mobile games developer and publisher Stillfront Group (OM:SF) completes the acquisition of Indian mobile social casino games developer Moonfrog Labs for a total of $90m.

Sweden-based gaming holding Modern Times Group (STO: MTG-B) has acquired a 30% stake in US-based multiplatform games developer Monumental after the latter acquired US-based browser games platform Kongregate. After the acquisition, Kongregate will be fully integrated into Monumental.
UK-based multiplatform games publisher and developer Team17 (LON: TM17) has entered into an agreement to acquire German PC&console games developer Astragon for up to $114m (€100m).

Video streaming giant Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) has entered into an agreement to acquire Finnish mobile gaming studio Next Games (FRA: 6NG). Netflix will pay $2.3 (€2.1) in cash per Next Games’ share, which will bring the total equity value of the studio to $72m (€65m).
US-based chess platform Chess.com, a subsidiary of Poker Stars, has acquired Norway-based chess platform Play Magnus for an undisclosed sum.
Israel-based mobile games developer Playtika (NASDAQ: PLTK) acquires Israel-based mobile games developer Innplay Labs for a total amount of up to $300m, including an upfront consideration of $80m.

Sweden-based games holding Stillfront Group acquires 100% of US-based mobile game developer and publisher Candywriter for an upfront consideration of $74.4m and potential earn-out consideration of $120.6m on a cash and debt free basis.
UK-based mobile casual game developer Tripledot Studios acquired Czech-based mobile casual and hypercasual games developer ZephyrMobile for an undisclosed sum.

US­-based social casino game developer PLAYSTUDIOS announced the acquisition of US-based mobile game company Brainium. A $70 million of the upfront will be paid in cash with consideration tied to the performance of Brainium for the period from the closing of the acquisition through December 31, 2022.

Mobile gaming company Gracevale owns Cubic Games, the publisher of Pixel Gun 3D. For the development of the game, the company also hires third-party mobile games developer Lightmap Studio. Nexters will acquire both Gracevale and Lightmap Studio for a total of $70m on a cash and debt-free basis, including the initial consideration of $59.5m and an earn-out payment of $10.5m.

Tencent (SEHK: 700) acquires US-based PC&console games studio Turtle Rock — the developers of Left 4 Dead, Evolve, and recent Back 4 Blood titles. The financial terms of the deal are not disclosed. However, Turtle Rock will continue to operate independently under existing leadership.

Sony Interactive Entertainment (TYO: 6758; NYSE: SONY) has acquired Finnish studio Housemarque, the developer of Returnal and Resogun, for an undisclosed sum. Sony and Housemarque have worked together on eight PlayStation exclusive projects in the span of 15 years — their most recent project is a roguelike third-person shooter Returnal for PS5

2K announced it has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire privately-held HB Studios Multimedia Ltd., developers of the critically acclaimed and commercially successful PGA TOUR® 2K21, as well as The Golf Club franchise.

Swedish video game holding company Embracer Group has announced the acquisition of Chinese mobile gaming studio Jufeng and its six gaming titles from Gaea. The newly bought studio will be operating under Deca Games — the sixth operative group within Embracer, working with the mobile gaming market.
Tencent’s mobile gaming subsidiary Miniclip has acquired UK-based multiplatform game developer Supersonic Software for an undisclosed sum.
Saudi-Arabia based company Savvy Gaming Group acquires two esports organizations ESL Gaming from Sweden-based MTG ($1.05b) and UK-based FACEIT ($450m) for a combined $1.5B in an all-cash transaction.

US-based mobile gaming and monetization company AppLovin (NASDAQ: APP) has completed the acquisition of mobile monetization platform MoPub from Twitter (NYSE: TWTR) for $1.05B. The deal was covered in detail in our Weekly News Digest #40.
Tencent has received approval from a UK High Court to acquire UK games outfit Sumo Group for $1.27 billion.

Embracer bought Borderlands creator Gearbox for $363 m upfront ( $188 m cash + $175 m Embracer B shares ) plus an earn-out of up to $1.015 bn payable over six years, giving it 100 % of the 550-person AAA studio and its IP. Deal signed 3 Feb 2021; completed 6 Apr 2021 as Embracer’s 7ᵗʰ operating group.

Playtika bought Israel-based Dice Dreams creator SuperPlay for US $ 700 m cash up-front and up to US $ 1.25 bn in three-year earn-outs, adding two top-grossing casual franchises, a 300-person Tel-Aviv studio and live-ops expertise to bolster its mobile portfolio

Turkey-based mobile games startup Spyke Games has raised $55m in Seed funding. The round was conducted by a single investor, Griffin Gaming Partners. Spyke plans to establish its position in the casual mobile gaming segment by using multiplayer functionality and other social elements.

Aristocrat agreed to buy Churchill Downs’ mobile- and social-gaming subsidiary Big Fish for US $ 990 m in cash, broadening its digital portfolio and doubling pro-forma digital revenue. The all-cash deal closed on 24 Jan 2018 after regulatory approvals.

Founders Samo & Iza Login sold 100 % of Talking Tom maker Outfit7 to a Hong Kong-based investor group led by United Luck for US $1 billion in cash. The share transfer completed 28 Dec 2016 and was publicly announced 20 Jan 2017, marking one of the largest CEE mobile-gaming exits to date.

Scopely acquired Sony Pictures’ GSN Games for ≈ $1 billion, paying half in cash and half in Scopely preferred equity that gave Sony a minority stake. The deal, announced 18 Oct 2021 and closed 6 Dec 2021, added Bingo Bash and Solitaire TriPeaks plus ~400 employees to Scopely’s casual/social-casino portfolio.

Other Investors: Haveli Investments
Description*: Carlyle agreed to sell RuneScape developer Jagex to a consortium of CVC Fund VIII (lead) and Haveli Investments for about £ 910 m (~$1.16 bn). The deal hands the studio’s 300 m-account MMO franchise and ~700 staff to new owners keen to expand “forever games” and pursue add-on M&A.

EA out-bid Take-Two and bought UK racing-game specialist Codemasters for US $1.2 bn cash (604 p per share), adding the F1, DIRT/GRID and Project CARS franchises plus ~700 staff; announced 14 Dec 2020, Court-sanctioned 16 Feb and completed 18 Feb 2021.

Embracer Group divested Cyprus-based mobile-puzzle publisher Easybrain (Sudoku.com, Blockudoku) to Miniclip for $1.2 bn cash. The deal, signed 14 Nov 2024 and closed 23 Jan 2025, gives Miniclip full ownership of Easybrain’s ad-driven portfolio (~ 450 m MAU) and 255 employees while allowing Embracer to slash net debt.

Tencent’s vehicle Image Frame took Hong-Kong-listed Leyou (owner of Warframe studio Digital Extremes & Splash Damage) private for HK$3.3219 cash per share (≈ US $1.32 bn equity). Scheme announced 27 Aug 2020, sanctioned 18 Dec 2020, effective 21 Dec 2020, giving Tencent 100 % of Leyou and delisting the company on 24 Dec 2020.

EA bought Golf Clash studio Playdemic from AT&T/Warner Bros. Games for $1.4 bn cash, adding a top-grossing sports-clash title and ~200 UK staff to deepen its mobile sports portfolio; signed 23 Jun 2021 and closed 20 Sep 2021.

Zynga bought Istanbul’s Peak Games for ≈ $1.8 bn (50 % cash, 50 % Zynga stock), adding Toon Blast & Toy Blast plus 100 staff; the deal, announced 1 Jun 2020 and closed 2 Jul 2020, instantly lifted Zynga’s mobile DAU base by >60 %

On February 8, 2021, Electronic Arts announced its agreement to acquire Glu Mobile for $2.1 billion in enterprise value. The deal involved EA purchasing Glu’s shares at $12.50 per share in cash, representing a 36% premium over Glu’s closing stock price on February 5, 2021. Positioning EA to significantly expand its presence in the mobile gaming sector

Netmarble agreed to buy 100 % of Hong Kong-based social-casino studio SpinX Games for US $2.19 bn cash, gaining hits such as Cash Frenzy and ~1 200 staff to diversify beyond RPGs; the deal was announced 2 Aug 2021 and completed 13 Oct 2021.
Microsoft bought Minecraft creator Mojang for $2.5 bn cash, gaining full ownership of the studio, IP and global community; the deal was announced 15 Sep 2014 and completed 6 Nov 2014.

Other Investors: BPEA, CPP Investments, Temasek
Description*: Swedish PE firm EQT (through BPEA VIII) teamed with CPP Investments and Temasek-backed Rosa Investments to buy Dublin-based outsourcing giant Keywords Studios for £2.21 bn cash (≈ $2.8 bn), or £24.50 per share, a 67 % premium to the undisturbed price. The court-sanctioned scheme was announced 2 Jul 2024, approved by shareholders on 3 Oct and completed 24 Oct 2024, taking Keywords private.

L&W bought the remaining ~17 % of SciPlay it didn’t own for $22.95 cash per share (≈ $496 m), turning the social-casino studio into a wholly-owned subsidiary. Deal signed 8 Aug 2023, closed 23 Oct 2023; SciPlay stock was delisted the same day.

Other Investors: Yunfeng Capital
Description*: Caesars Interactive sold its Israeli social-casino powerhouse Playtika to a Chinese consortium led by Giant for $4.4 bn in cash. Playtika remains independent under CEO Robert Antokol while the buyers gain a top-grossing mobile-casino portfolio and global live-ops know-how.

Saudi-owned mobile giant Scopely will buy Niantic’s games portfolio for $3.5 bn cash, adding the 30 m-MAU Pokémon GO ecosystem and two other live AR titles. Niantic will distribute $350 m to shareholders and spin off its geospatial-AI platform as Niantic Spatial. Deal announced 12 Mar 2025, with closing slated for late-2025.

Sony bought Destiny developer Bungie for $3.6 bn to secure live-service expertise, keep the studio multi-platform, and support Sony’s goal of launching 10+ live-service titles by 2026 while giving Bungie resources to build new IP and trans-media projects.

US $ 3.6 bn (100 % equity) — includes c. $2.4 bn paid for the shares and c. $1.2 bn earmarked for multi-year employee-retention incentives

Other Investors: ByteDance
Description*: ByteDance’s Nuverse unit bought Mobile Legends developer Moonton for ≈ $4 bn, out-bidding Tencent to secure a marquee mobile-MOBA franchise and live-ops expertise for its global expansion push. The studio continues to operate independently under CEO Justin Yuan.

Saudi PIF-backed Savvy Games Group bought Culver City-based mobile publisher Scopely for US $4.9 billion cash, making it Savvy’s flagship content arm. The deal was signed 5 Apr 2023 and, after regulatory clearances, closed 12 Jul 2023; Scopely now operates autonomously under Savvy, continuing to scale hits such as Marvel Strike Force and Monopoly GO!.

Activision Blizzard agreed to pay $18 per share in cash (total $5.9 bn) for Candy Crush maker King, securing a top-grossing mobile portfolio and >500 m MAU to complement its console/PC franchises and accelerate growth across mobile, subscription and free-to-play.

Microsoft announced on 21 Sep 2020 that it would purchase 100 % of privately-held ZeniMax Media, parent of Bethesda Softworks and eight other studios, for USD 7.5 billion in cash.  The deal, cleared by US, EU and other regulators, closed on 9 Mar 2021 and added blockbuster IP such as The Elder Scrolls, Fallout and Doom to Microsoft’s first-party Xbox portfolio.

On 21 June 2016 Tencent announced that it would acquire an 84.3 % controlling stake in Finnish mobile-games studio Supercell from SoftBank for an equity consideration of US $ 8.6 bn, valuing Supercell at US $ 10.2 bn enterprise value.  The deal, executed through Luxembourg vehicle Halti S.A., closed on 18 October 2016 after Chinese, U.S. CFIUS and Finnish approvals.  Tencent’s consortium partners include Hillhouse and CITIC Capital; Supercell’s founders and employees retained the remaining shares.  The acquisition gives Tencent top-grossing global mobile hits Clash of Clansand Clash Royale.

Take-Two agreed to acquire mobile-gaming giant Zynga for $12.7 bn, paying $3.50 cash + 0.0406 TTWO shares (≈ $6.36) per Zynga share—a 64 % premium. The deal gives Take-Two a top-five mobile publisher, >183 m MAUs and strong live-ops know-how to diversify beyond console/PC.

Microsoft agreed to acquire Call of Duty publisher Activision Blizzard for $68.7 bn cash, the largest video-game deal ever, to add 30 studios and blockbuster IPs (CoD, Warcraft, Candy Crush) to Xbox Game Pass and accelerate its cross-platform, live-service strategy.
